docs.lead_paragraph: How many economists does it take to fix the United States health care system?

headline.main: A Bipartisan Proposal on Health Care Costs

docs.abstract: Bipartisan economists' recommendations for tackling medical costs include taxing sugary soft drinks and reducing employers' tax subsidies for providing health insurance.
docs.snippet: Bipartisan economists' recommendations for tackling medical costs include taxing sugary soft drinks and reducing employers' tax subsidies for providing health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: 1.) Japan's new government plans to move away from deregulation and market-led growth. Is that the right course?
docs.abstract: How much would it cost to spend eternity with Marilyn Monroe, and more.
docs.snippet: How much would it cost to spend eternity with Marilyn Monroe, and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new survey finds that whether someone believes controversial statements about the health care overhaul depends on that person's political affiliation.
docs.abstract: Whether you believe in various things the Obama administration says are myths depends on your political affiliation.
docs.snippet: Whether you believe in various things the Obama administration says are myths depends on your political affiliation.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the Well blog this morning, Tara Parker-Pope tells the tale of a young man in Las Vegas who had a serious heart condition but no insurance, despite working part-time as a D.J. and graphic designer. His case, she writes, "stands out as a striking example of both the best and the worst that the American health care system has to offer - extraordinary medical prowess that is too often out of reach for all but the luckiest and best insured." Read the story.

headline.main: In Need of a New Heart, but Uninsured

docs.abstract: On the Well blog, the story of a young man who needed a heart transplant but had no insurance.
docs.snippet: On the Well blog, the story of a young man who needed a heart transplant but had no insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: Taking an enemy-of-my-enemy approach, two challengers to Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania plan to get together Wednesday night for a public forum on health care.

headline.main: An Enemy of Senator Specter Is Their Friend

docs.abstract: Two Pennsylvania challengers to the Senate seat of Arlen Specter plan a health care town-hall debate -- without him.
docs.snippet: Two Pennsylvania challengers to the Senate seat of Arlen Specter plan a health care town-hall debate -- without him.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most Americans still admire the president and want him to succeed. But if he doesn’t proceed in a manner consistent with the spirit of the nation and the times, voters will find a way to stop him.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a special election for a Congressional seat in a solidly Democratic part of San Francisco, health care has been a topic of choice for several candidates.

docs.lead_paragraph: A small film for Welsh teenagers has been viewed millions of times. That may not mean changed behavior.

headline.print_headline: Some Doubts About Scare Tactics on Drivers Who Text

docs.lead_paragraph: New York’s texting-while-driving ban will receive “secondary” enforcement: a fine may be imposed only if the police find some other violation at the same time.

headline.seo: Law Against Texting and Driving Has Little Clout
headline.main: Use of Thumbs Confounds Use of Sense

docs.lead_paragraph: Permanent residents who have had green cards for less than five years will lose dental and hospice care.
